article.title: LIVE: California Midterm Election Results 2018
article.description: The Nexus will be updating this page with live results from the California Midterm Election and the Santa Barbara County election.
article.content:
The Nexus will be updating this page with live results from the Nov. 6 California Midterm Election and the Santa Barbara County election. We will also be live-tweeting additional results.

Governor:

Vote by Mail and Mailed Ballot Results: Gavin Newsom (D) leads with 54.65% of the vote. His opponent, John Cox (R), trails with 45.35% of the vote as of 8:02 p.m.

  • 9:27 p.m. Newsom has 54.72%, Cox has 45.28%
  • 9:50 p.m. Newsom has 55.05%, Cox has 44.95%
  • 10:06 p.m. Newsom has 56.02%, Cox has 43.98%
  • 10:17 p.m. Newsom has 57.41%, Cox has 42.59%
  • 10:39 p.m. Newsom has 59.50%, Cox has 40.50%
  • 10:56 p.m. Newsom has 58.99%, Cox has 41.01%
  • 11:25 p.m. Newsom has 57.74%, Cox has 40.97% of the vote, with 100% of precincts now reporting.

Secretary of State:

Vote by Mail and Mailed Ballot Results: Alex Padilla (D) leads with 57.05% of the vote. His opponent, Mark Meuser (R), follows with 42.95% of the vote as of 8:02 p.m.

  • 9:27 p.m. Padilla has 57.12%, Meuser has 42.88%
  • 9:50 p.m. Padilla has 57.46%, Meuser has 42.54%
  • 10:06 p.m. Padilla has 58.40%, Meuser has 41.60%
  • 10:17 p.m. Padilla has 59.78%, Meuser has 40.22%
  • 10:39 p.m. Padilla has 61.91%, Meuser has 38.09%
  • 10:56 p.m. Padilla has 61.50%, Meuser has 38.50%
  • 11:25 p.m. Padilla has 59.60%, Meuser has 37.50% of the vote, with 100% of the precincts now reporting.

California Senator:

Vote by Mail and Mailed Ballot Results: Dianne Feinstein (D) leads with 54.87% of the vote. Her opponent, Kevin De Leon (D) trails with 45.13% of the vote as of 8:02 p.m.

  • 9:27 p.m. Feinstein has 54.94%, De Leon has 45.06%
  • 9:50 p.m. Feinstein has 55.15%, De Leon has 45.85%
  • 10:06 p.m. Feinstein has 55.36%, De Leon has 44.64%
  • 10:17 p.m. Feinstein has 55.65%, De Leon has 44.35%
  • 10:39 p.m. Feinstein has 55.78%, De Leon has 44.22%
  • 10:56 p.m. Feinstein has 55.56%, De Leon has 44.44%
  • 11:25 p.m. Feinstein has 47.58%, De Leon has 38.41% of the vote, with 100% of the precincts now reporting.

24th Congressional District (Santa Barbara and San Luis Obispo Counties) Representative:

Vote by Mail and Mailed Ballot Results: Salud Carbajal (D) leads with 55.82% of the vote. His opponent, Justin Fareed (R), follows with 44.18% of the vote as of 8:02 p.m.

  • 9:27 p.m. Carbajal has 55.89%, Fareed has 44.11%
  • 9:50 p.m. Carbajal has 56.26%, Fareed has 43.74%
  • 10:06 p.m. Carbajal has 57.21%, Fareed has 42.79%
  • 10:17 p.m. Carbajal has 58.63%, Fareed has 41.37%
  • 10:39 p.m. Carbajal has 60.77%, Fareed has 39.23%
  • 10:56 p.m. Carbajal has 60.30%, Fareed has 39.70%
  • 11:25 p.m. Carbajal has 58.96%, Fareed has 39.58% of the vote, with 100% of the precincts reported

State Assembly 37th District Representative:

Vote by Mail and Mailed Ballot Results: Monique Limón (D) leads with 82.84%. Her opponent, David Norrdin (D), follows with 17.16% of the vote.

  • 9:27 p.m. Limón has 82.86%, Norrdin has 17.14%
  • 9:50 p.m. Limón has 82.88%, Norrdin has 17.12%
  • 10:06 p.m. Limón has 83.18%, Norrdin has 16.82%
  • 10:17 p.m. Limón has 83.68%, Norrdin has 16.32%
  • 10:39 p.m. Limón has 84.29%, Norrdin has 15.71%
  • 10:56 p.m. Limón has 84.03%, Norrdin has 15.97%
  • 11:25 p.m. Limón has 67.23%, Norrdin has 13.03% of the vote, with 100% of precincts now reporting.

Goleta Union School District:

Vote by Mail and Mailed Ballot Results: Luz Reyes-Martin leads with 32.18% of the vote. Her opponents follow with 30.63% of the vote (Richard Mayer), 25.16% of the vote (Carin Ezal), 11.31% of the vote (Bruce Wallach.)

  • 9:27 p.m. Reyes-Martin has 32.18%, Mayer has 30.63%, Ezal has 25.16% and Wallach has 11.31%
  • 9:50 p.m. Reyes-Martin has 32.25%, Mayer has 30.59%, Ezal has 25.09% and Wallach has 11.35%
  • 10:06 p.m. Reyes-Martin has 32.64%, Mayer has 30.29%, Ezal has 24.86% and Wallach has 11.53%
  • 10:17 p.m. Reyes-Martin has 33.19%, Mayer has 29.96%, Ezal has 24.70% and Wallach has 11.51%
  • 10:39 p.m. Reyes-Martin has 33.84%, Mayer has 29.73%, Ezal has 24.09% and Wallach has 11.69%
  • 10:39 p.m. Reyes-Martin has 33.90%, Mayer has 29.70%, Ezal has 24.09% and Wallach has 11.65%
  • 11:25 p.m. Reyes-Martin has 54.73%, Mayer has 47.55%, Ezal has 38.79% and Wallach has 18.71% of the vote, with 100% of precincts now reporting.

Ballot Measures:

Measure G2018 (Re-Districting Initiative) County Ordinance:

Vote by Mail and Mailed Ballot Results: 48.53% no, 51.47% yes

  • 9:27 p.m. 51.51% yes, 48.45% no
  • 9:50 p.m. 51.82% yes, 48.18% no
  • 10:06 p.m. 52.31% yes, 47.69% no
  • 10:17 p.m. 53.09% yes, 46.91% no
  • 10:39 p.m. 54.20% yes, 45.80% no
  • 10:56 p.m. 53.76% yes, 46.24% no
  • 11:25 p.m. 46.42% yes, 41.19% no, with 100% of precincts now reporting.

Measure H2018 (Re-Districting Initiative) County Initiative:

Vote by Mail and Mailed Ballot Results: 68.24% no, 31.76% yes

  • 9:27 p.m. 68.24% no, 31.76% yes
  • 9:50 p.m. 68.27% no, 31.73% yes
  • 10:06 p.m. 68.23% no, 31.77% yes
  • 10:17 p.m. 68.06% no, 31.94% yes
  • 10:39 p.m. 67.88% no, 32.12% yes
  • 10:56 p.m. 67.61% no, 32.39% yes
  • 11:25 p.m. 57.12% no, 27.65% yes, with 100% of precincts now reporting.

Measure Z2018 City Goleta Cannabis Tax:

Vote by Mail and Mailed Ballot Results: 83.33% yes, 16.67% no

  • 9:27 p.m. 83.33% yes, 16.67% no
  • 9:50 p.m. 83.34% yes, 16.66% no
  • 10:06 p.m. 83.34% yes, 16.66% no
  • 10:17 p.m. 82.99% yes, 17.01% no
  • 10:39 p.m. 82.34% yes, 17.66% no
  • 10:56 p.m. 81.95% yes, 18.05% no
  • 11:25 p.m. 77.76% yes, 17.16% no, with 100% of precincts now reporting.

related.title: I.V. Resident Arrested for Residential Burglary
related.description: The suspect is not affiliated with UC Santa Barbara or Santa Barbara City College, according to SBSO spokesperson Kelly Hoover.
related.content:
A 23-year-old Isla Vista resident was arrested on charges of residential burglary early Saturday morning, according to the Santa Barbara Sheriff’s Office (SBSO).

The suspect, Lovens Laurore, was arrested after SBSO responded to the report of a “burglary in progress” on the 6700 block of Del Playa at approximately 4:20 a.m., according to an SBSO press release sent out on Saturday night.

Laurore was arrested early Saturday morning for residential burglary. Courtesy of SBSO.

Laurore is not affiliated with UC Santa Barbara or Santa Barbara City College, according to SBSO spokesperson Kelly Hoover.

The victim called 911 after returning home and finding Laurore “rummaging through his apartment,” according to the press release.

Further investigation revealed that Laurore entered the residence through an unlocked door, according to the release.

Laurore had collected “several pieces of high-end clothing” and a MacBook computer before attempting to flee, but the victim and a housemate detained him until law enforcement officials arrived.

He is being held on a $50,000 bail at the Santa Barbara County Jail.

Sheriff’s deputies later discovered that Laurore is on probation for “possession of stolen property,” according to the press release.

SBSO is currently conducting an investigation.

Anyone with additional information is asked to call the I.V. Foot Patrol at 805-681-4179 or to leave an anonymous tip at 805-681-4171. An anonymous tip can also be submitted here.

Print
Evelyn Spence

Evelyn Spence harbors a great love for em dashes and runs on nothing but iced coffee, Jolly Ranchers and breaking news. She serves as the managing editor and can be reached at evelyn@dailynexus.com, managing@dailynexus.com or at @evelynrosesc on Twitter.

related.title: Court Requests Push iV Menus Owner’s Rape Hearing to June
related.description: Galoustian, 45, was arrested in December on four felony charges, including kidnap to commit robbery or rape, rape of a drugged victim and two counts of oral copulation by use of force or injury.
related.content:
Patrick Galoustian has owned iV Menus, a popular Isla Vista food delivery service, since 2008. McLane Brown/Daily Nexus

A superior court judge ruled Thursday iV Menus owner Patrick Galoustian will have his preliminary hearing date setting on June 6 as the prosecution obtains further pre-trial evidence.

Galoustian, 45, was arrested in December on four felony charges, including kidnap to commit robbery or rape, rape of a drugged victim and two counts of oral copulation by use of force or injury. He is being held on combined $1.5 million bail. 

Before his arrest, Galoustian owned and operated iV Menus, a popular Isla Vista-based food delivery service, for nine years.

On Thursday afternoon, Judge Thomas R. Adams announced his decision to postpone Galoustian’s case to June 6, citing five outstanding requests for discovery by the prosecution. In the legal system, discovery is a method that either party can use to obtain more pre-trial evidence.

“We’ll get the actual discovery and be ready to rock and roll by the first weekend of June,” Adams told the courtroom.

After changing attorneys, Galoustian is now represented by Robert Sanger, who served as co-counsel for pop legend Michael Jackson in 2005 when the late idol was tried for child molestation. Galoustian was previously represented by Mindi Boulet.

Galoustian is a 2003 UC Santa Barbara alumnus. His preliminary setting hearing has been postponed three times after being originally scheduled on Jan. 11.

Updated April 6, 2:33 p.m.

Print

related.title: Senate Passes Resolution To Preserve El Centro Building
related.description: The Associated Students Senate passed a resolution to preserve the El Centro Arnulfo Casillas Activity Room Wednesday following concerns that the historic building would be demolished in 45 days.
related.content:
A.S. Senate passed a resolution on Wednesday to preserve El Centro Arnulfo Casillas Activity Room, which is used by several different cultural organizations on campus. Stephen Manga / Daily Nexus

The Associated Students Senate passed a resolution to preserve the El Centro Arnulfo Casillas Activity Room Wednesday following concerns that the historic building would be demolished in 45 days.

The 40-year-old building is located behind the UCSB Library and is used as a gathering space for several cultural organizations, including El Congreso, Mujer, Students for Justice in Palestine and conglomerate Mesa Directiva.

Senators Lesly Silva and Jesse Velasquez authored the resolution and presented it at Wednesday’s A.S. Senate meeting. The resolution supports student groups who have pushed to preserve the building, asking that it be recognized as a cultural artifact.

“El Centro Arnulfo Casillas is an open space that can be used and is used by many groups from every race, religion, gender identity, ethnicity, socioeconomic background, status, and creed,” the resolution states.

Campus building official Ed Schmittgen sent a notice to campus architect Marc Fisher on Jan. 9 saying that consultants found the trailer’s integrity was compromised following inspection.

The report lists insect infestation and dry rot on the building’s floor, rust and corrosion on supporting steel beams and lack of adequate ventilation beneath the trailer’s floor. It concludes that the building’s problems create an unsafe condition in case of an earthquake.

The building was categorized as a “severe” life risk per the UC Seismic Policy, Schmittgen said, and advised that the building be either improved or demolished in 45 days’ time. Administrators suggested that although the trailer would be difficult to preserve due to its 10-year lifespan, the building’s artwork could be relocated.

Over 50 students gathered in the El Centro annex the following Friday to negotiate other options with campus administration. Among those in attendance were Schmittgen, Vice Chancellor for Student Affairs Margaret Klawunn and Vice Chancellor of Campus Design and Facilities Marc Fisher.

Students listed several concerns, saying the 45-day evacuation timeline was restrictive, administrators had not maintained the building properly and the University could not remove students’ home-away-from-home.

Though UCSB received distinction and grant money as a Hispanic Serving Institution in 2016, the A.S. resolution states “the Hispanic and Latinx community has seen little to no return on this money that their communities have been promised.”

“It is clearly stated that ‘We, the UCSB Associated Students 67th Senate, represent and advocate for the undergraduate student body and strive to effectively address their concerns,’ and there is a clear argument that a large group of students who depend on this space want the 67th Senate to act upon their concerns and support them,” the resolution adds.

On Wednesday, the A.S. Senate passed the resolution without objection.

“At this point this has been an ongoing battle for about 45 years,” Senator Silva said. “The whole goal is to finally end this and make it a permanent space that isn’t being constantly threatened.”

Students will gather in the El Centro Arnulfo Casillas Activity Room for another meeting with administration on Friday at 3 p.m.

A version of this story appeared on p.3 of the Thursday, Jan. 19, 2017 print edition of the Daily Nexus.

Print
